subject: CSS
question: Why do all flex elements (children) grow by default to the same height of the tallest element?
answer:
Because all children of a flex parent have by default the property align-items, and the initial value is stretch.
The items stretch to the height of the flex container, which in this case is defined by the tallest item. The items all line up at the start of the container, leaving any extra space at the end of the row.
